presenters.name: Dr. Kelley Misata ⓘ
presenters.bio: Dr. Kelley Misata is the President and Executive Director of the Open Information Security Foundation (OISF), the nonprofit behind Suricata, the widely used open-source network threat detection engine. With over 15 years of experience in cybersecurity strategy, open-source sustainability, and community building, she has guided Suricata’s growth from a research initiative to a trusted global solution. Known for bridging the gap between technical teams and real-world impact, Dr. Misata brings a strategic, people-first approach to sustaining open-source tools in modern security ecosystems.

schedule.topic: Beyond Code Commits: Sustaining Open Source for Security at Scale ⓘ
schedule.description:
Security teams around the world depend on open source tools like Suricata and Security Onion—but few understand what it takes to keep them going. In this talk, Dr. Kelley Misata, President of OISF, shares the behind-the-scenes reality of sustaining one of the most widely used open source engines in network security. It’s not just about code—it’s about people, governance, funding, trust, and long-term vision.

From balancing commercial interests with community needs to navigating funding gaps and project sprawl, this talk delivers real stories and practical lessons from over a decade of open source leadership. Whether you’re a maintainer, contributor, or user, you’ll walk away with a deeper appreciation of what “supporting open source” really means—and why it matters more than ever.

presenters.name: Matt Gracie ⓘ
presenters.bio: Matthew Gracie is a defensive security specialist with fifteen years of Blue Team experience in higher education, manufacturing, financial services, and healthcare. He is currently a Senior Engineer at Security Onion Solutions, as well as an adjunct professor of Cybersecurity in the graduate school at Canisius University. Matt is also the lead organizer of Infosec 716, a monthly meetup for security enthusiasts in Western New York, and the BSides Buffalo technology conference. He enjoys good beer, mountain bikes, open source security tools, and college hockey, and can be found on Bluesky as @InfosecGoon.

schedule.topic: Security Onion as a Teaching Platform ⓘ
schedule.description: In the Fall semester of 2023, I began teaching a new Cybersecurity Operations course in the graduate program at Canisius University. My goal was simple - to give students exposure to both the high-level concepts and hands-on skills that they would need to be successful blue teamers after they graduate. This talk is about how I integrated Security Onion into the class as a teaching platform to provide that experience in detection engineering, alert investigation, threat hunting, and more.

presenters.name: Wes Lambert ⓘ
presenters.bio: Wes Lambert is a lead engineer at Target, where he focuses on network security monitoring at scale. He spends his time designing and tuning network-based detection architecture and helps the organization achieve visibility across the enterprise.

schedule.topic: AI2Tune - Auto-tuning NSM for Optimal Operation ⓘ
schedule.description:
Tuning NSM sensors is often tedious, reactive, and error-prone. Teams spend many hours manually tuning Zeek and Suricata configurations to balance detection fidelity with packet loss and operational overhead. Static tuning approaches often fall short in dynamic environments, leading to degraded performance and operational frustration.

AI2Tune is an open framework designed to auto-tune network sensors for optimal operation. By combining machine learning and adaptive heuristics, AI2Tune continuously analyzes performance telemetry, such as packet drops, queue stats and system utilization, recommending or applying configuration changes in real time.

This presentation will demonstrate how AI2Tune learns baseline behavior, predicts emerging bottlenecks, and dynamically adjusts sensor configuration to maintain reliable coverage. While AI2Tune is platform-agnostic, examples will focus on integrating with Security Onion deployments, including strategies for safely applying tuning changes via SaltStack and maintaining compatibility with managed configurations.

AI2Tune can ingest metrics from ElasticSearch, InfluxDB, Prometheus, and local logs, detect deteriorating performance patterns, and trigger adjustments through Salt, Ansible, or API workflows. The system supports fully automated or recommendation-only modes, giving operators flexibility and visibility into each tuning decision.

Attendees will see practical examples of how AI2Tune can improve sensor performance, enhance operational resilience, and will become familiar with lessons learned from deploying adaptive tuning.

presenters.name: Dr. Chris Sanders ⓘ
presenters.bio: Dr. Chris Sanders is an information security instructor, author, and researcher focused on the intersection of cyber security,  education, and cognitive psychology where he studies security analyst cognition and performance. He is the founder of Applied Network Defense, a cyber security training company, and Executive Director of the Rural Technology Fund, a non-profit that provides technology education resources to rural public schools and libraries. In previous roles, Chris worked with the US Department of Defense, InGuardians, and Mandiant. He is the author of several information security books, including Intrusion Detection Honeypots, Applied Network Security Monitoring, and Practical Packet Analysis. Chris received his doctorate in education from Baylor University. He spends his free time building things from wood and studying space rocks.

presenters.name: Josh Brower ⓘ
presenters.bio: Josh Brower has been crashing computers since his teens, and now he's fortunate enough to do it professionally as a Principal Engineer at Security Onion Solutions. With 17 years in Information Security, he focuses primarily on network and endpoint detection, helping defenders stay one step ahead of attackers. He's also passionate about making security more accessible, especially for non-technical audiences. Whether it's explaining how digital actions have real-world consequences or sharing practical ways to reduce risk, Josh enjoys helping others navigate the digital world more safely.

schedule.description:
Investigation playbooks should never be used to replace or restrict human analysts completely, but they can augment analysts by helping them overcome the limitations of their memory, generate new ideas for specific investigation scenarios, minimize the limitations of their intuition, and consolidate individual knowledge.

In this talk, we'll introduce a new framework and standard for creating Human-Centered Investigation Playbooks. The goal for these playbooks is simple: provide a structure for documenting investigative playbooks that is flexible, intuitive, and genuinely helpful to human analysts during incident investigation and response.

Chris Sanders will begin by unpacking the theory behind this human-centered approach, grounded in cognitive science and investigative reasoning. You'll learn how traditional playbooks fall short, and how cognitive playbooks can improve decision-making, reduce analyst fatigue, and enable consistent, high-quality outcomes.

After that, Josh Brower will demonstrate how this model has been integrated into Security Onion, showing off the new Guided Analysis feature that was recently released. He'll walk through a real-world example of a detection scenario using a playbook built into the platform, highlighting how the tool empowers analysts to make informed choices.

Finally, we'll wrap up by describing some best practices for creating playbooks as an educational exercise with a practical outcome. Analysts, SOC leaders, and tool builders should walk away from this talk with a better understanding of how to effectively use investigative playbooks, and a few tools for helping them along that path.

presenters.name: Doug Burks ⓘ
presenters.bio: Doug Burks started Security Onion in 2008 to provide a comprehensive platform to help folks peel back the layers of their enterprise and make their adversaries cry. Today, Security Onion has over 2,000,000 downloads and is being used by organizations around the world for threat hunting, enterprise security monitoring, and log management. In 2014, Doug started Security Onion Solutions LLC to help those organizations by providing training, professional services, and hardware appliances. Doug is a CEO, public speaker, teacher, former president of the Greater Augusta ISSA, and co-founder of BSides Augusta, but what he really likes the most is catching bad guys.
